events.description: Bitcoin recovered to over $65,000 after hitting a two-year low.
A significant selloff across various cryptocurrencies occurring in early February.

facts.fact_text: Bitcoin rebounded above $65,000 from a two-year low of $60,000 on Friday.

evidences.evidence_text: Bitcoin rebounded above $65,000 from the two-year low of $60,000 earlier on Friday

facts.fact_text: Bitcoin is trading at approximately 30% lower year-to-date.
Bitcoin's current value is about half of its record high reached four months ago.

evidences.evidence_text: trading at around half the value since its record high four months prior

claims.claim_text: Investors bought Bitcoin because prices were perceived as cheap following a plunge.

evidences.evidence_text: investors took advantage of cheaper prices following the plunge across cryptocurrencies in early February

claims.claim_text: Increased institutional ownership has made Bitcoin more susceptible to derisking trends.

evidences.evidence_text: The higher share of Bitcoin in institutional portfolios made it more vulnerable to derisking

claims.claim_text: The decline in retail crypto holdings is caused by the availability of other speculative substitutes like AI ETFs and zero-day options.
claims.author: Other portions of the market

evidences.evidence_text: Other portions of the market also tie the decline in cryptocurrency holdings by retail traders on the broader range of substitutes for speculative trading

evidence.evidence_text: The higher share of Bitcoin in institutional portfolios made it more vulnerable to derisking
derisking, which recently dominated trades following higher volatility and margin requirements in precious and base metal derivatives
tie the decline in cryptocurrency holdings by retail traders on the broader range of substitutes for speculative trading, including leveraged ETFs with exposure to AI companies
